inference: Final Answer: \\boxed{108}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: The measure of an interior angle in a regular pentagon is  $$\frac{180(5-2)}{5}=108^{\circ},$$ so $\angle QPT = 108^\circ$.  From isosceles triangle $PQT$, we have $\angle PQT = (180^\circ - \angle QPT)/2 = 36^\circ$.  Similarly, $\angle RQS = 36^\circ$.  Finally, $\triangle SQT$ is isosceles with $SQ=QT$, so median $\overline{QX}$ is also an angle bisector of $\angle SQT$.  Since $\angle SQT = \angle PQR - 36^\circ-36^\circ = 108^\circ-36^\circ-36^\circ = 36^\circ$, we have $\angle XQS = (\angle SQT)/2 = \boxed{18^\circ}$.

From isosceles triangle $PQT$, we have $\angle PQT = (180^\circ - \angle QPT)/2 = 36^\circ$.  Similarly, $\angle RQS = 36^\circ$.  Finally, $\triangle SQT$ is isosceles with $SQ=QT$, so median $\overline{QX}$ is also an angle bisector of $\angle SQT$.
